fields.headline: This week's new events
fields.bodyText: Adhocracy, London Beloved of 1970s radicals, the DIY ethos of achieving culture and co-operation without bureaucracy – or a big budget – is as relevant today as it's ever been. Fraternise with free thinkers ranging from punk potter Carrie Reichardt to "socialist magician" Ian Saville, be inspired by the Empty Shops Network's use of reclaimed spaces, or spend cash with a conscience at The People Speak's "democratic gameshow", where the audience choose how to invest the evening's takings. Finally, get decentralised on the dancefloor at Cut A Shine's high-energy hoedown. Rich Mix, E1, Sat & Sun Colette Bernhardt The Way Of The Dude, London At the box office The Big Lebowski was more of a slothful couch potato than a go-getting Gordon Gekko, but its legacy has been just as influential as the "greed is good" ethos of Wall Street, only with less shouting and more milk-based cocktails. Dudeism, a quasi-religion based upon the teachings of the film's antihero The Dude, has been the result of its slow-burn success and this event brings its founder Oliver Benjamin to the Idler magazine's west London slacker school for a debate on tenpin bowling, naps and kicking back. Tom Hodgkinson, John Naish and Ben Walters join Benjamin at the altar. The Idler Academy, W2, Wed Iain Aitch Relentless Boardmasters, Newquay Think surfing, think the Beach Boys. Think skateboarding, and it's a short leap to an internal jukebox loop of horrendous nu-metal. So a festival encompassing all of surf, skate and music is obviously a very good idea, and one which has evolved nicely since Boardmasters first emerged in 1983. This year's music bill takes in Wolf Gang, Eliza Doolittle, Bombay Bicycle Club and Fatboy Slim, but it's the awe-inspiring skills on show on the water – including the festival's first outing of longboarding – that will create the greatest stir. Fistral Beach and Watergate Bay, Wed to 14 Aug Stuart Goodwin Out & about International Folklore Festival, Billingham, Sat to 13 Aug Trad fare, taking in dance, music and crafts. Contains mild panpipery. Various venues John Piper Weekend, Eastbourne, Sat & Sun Talks, workshops and films on the landscape painter, tying in with the gallery's current Piper exhibition. Towner, events free, exhibition £5.50, concs £4, under 16s free Traquair Fair, Innerleithen, Sat & Sun Fire-themed traditional music, dance, kids theatre, storytelling and – yes! – voodoo unicyclists. Traquair House, Peeblesshire Apple Cart Festival, London, Sun With Tim Minchin, Chilly Gonzales and Saint Etienne, plus cabaret and book readings. Victoria Park, E3 El Sueño Existe, Machynlleth, Fri Not-as-unlikely-as-it-sounds mix of Welsh and Latin American music, dance, poetry, and political discussion. The Plas
